div.l: As pillyd as an ape was his sculle
He was a market beter at the fulle
Ther durst no wight hand vppon hym legge
That he ne swor a non he shuld abegge
A theef he was of corn and of mele
And that a sligh vsand for to stele
His name was callyd deynous symkyn
A wyfe he had comyn of noble kyn
The ꝑpersone of the tow hir fadir was
With hir he gafe many a peny pānnepenypānne of bras
For that symkyn shuld in his blood alye
She fostrid waswas in a gretgret nonnerye
For symkyn wold no wyfe as he said
But yif she were wel norisshid ⁊and a mayd
To sauyn in his estate in yomanrye
And she was proud and pert as isis a pye
A ful fayre sight yt was vppon hem two
Vppon OnVpponOn the haly day beforn hir wold he go
With his tippet boundyn about his hed
And she cam aftir in a kyte of Red ·
And symkyn had hosys of the same
Ther durst no wight clepyn hir but dame
TherTher Was non so hardy that went by the way
That with hirhir durst rage or onesones play
But yif he wold be slayn of symkyn
With panade knyfe or withwith boydekyn
For ielous folk ben ꝑperlous eủer mo
Algate thei wold here wyfes wend so
And eke for soothsooth she was sum del smoterlich
She was als deynous as watyr in a dich
And ful of hokyr and of bysmare
Hir thought that a lady shuld hir spare
For hir kynrede and hir nortery
That she had lernyd in the nonnery
A doughtir had thei betwix them two
Of xxᵗⁱ yeer without anyany mo
Saufyng a child that was of half yeer age
In cradil yt lay yt was a ꝓpropre page
The wench thikke and wel growyn was
With cammyssh nosenose eyen grey as yt were glas
Buttokkys brode and breest rounde and hye
But right fayre was hir heer I wil not lye ·
This TheThisThe ꝑperson of this town for she was so fayre
In purpose he was to make hir his ayre
Bothe of his catel and of his mesuage
And straunge he made of hir mariage
His purpose was to be stow hir hye
In to sum wurthi blood of aun̄cetrye
For holy chirche good mot be dispendid
On holy chirches blood þat is descendid
Therfore he wold his holy blood honour
Though that he holy chirche shuld deuour
// Gret sokyn hath this myllere without dout
With whete and malt vppon of allvpponof all land about
And namly ther was a gret colage
Men clepid the soler halle at caun̄brigge
Ther was her whete and eke her malt yy groun̄de
And on a day yt happyd in a stounde
Seek lay the maunciple of a maledy
Men wend wistly that he shuld dy
For the which this myllere stal boþeboþboþe mele ⁊and corn̄
A hundird tyme more than he did beforn
For therbeforn̄ he stal bot curtesly
But now he was a theef outragiously
For which the wardeyn chidde ⁊and made fare
But therof sette the myllere not a tare
He crakyd bost and swore yt was no so
~ Then were ther pouer clerkys two
That duellyd in this halle whiche I seye
Testyf thei were and lusty to pleye
Vppon the wardeyn bisily thei crye
Only for her myrth and for here iaperye
To gif hem leue but a litil stounde
To go the mylle and se ther corn̄ grounde
And hardily thei durst ley theyr necke
The myller shuld not stele hem half a pecke
Of corn̄ by sleight ne by force hem reue
And at the last the warden gaf hem leue
Iohan hight þat on and aleyn hight þat oþir
Of a toun̄ were thei bothe þat hight strothir
Fer in the North can I not telle where
This aleyn makith redy al his gere
And on an hors this sekke he cast a non̄
Forth goth aleyn the clerk and also Iohn
With good swerd and bookler by his syde
Iohan knew the estres wayestresway hem nedith no guyde
And and at þe mille þe sekke doun̄ he layth
Aleyn spak furst alheyl symound in faith
How farys thi fayre doughtir ⁊and þi wyfe
Aleyn quoth symkyn right wel by my lyfe
